Heath Robinson, a Navy SEAL Senior Chief, heroically rescued a fallen teammate during a 2010 nighttime raid against a heavily armed Taliban commander. Without hesitation, Heath engaged the enemy and provided critical covering fire while his teammates moved their mortally wounded companion to safety, earning a Bronze Star for his valorâ€”a true hero.

Tragically, 17 months later, on August 6, 2011, Heath was killed in action when his helicopter was shot down over Afghanistan. Today, he rests in Section 60 at Arlington National Cemetery. I have the utmost respect & admiration for our nationâ€™s Gold Star families, for the ultimate sacrifices they have made in service to our country. They represent the very best of our great nation.

Myth: The Reorganization Act of 1984 was passed to cure a procedural defect in the original congressional review process for Presidential reorganization plans, after the one-house veto was held unconstitutional in INS v. Chadha - and that stops the President from acting unilaterally.

Truth: The Reorganization Act of 1984 had a clear and full expiration date of its own (just like the Reorganization Act of 1977). During its effective period, it required Congress to affirmatively approve presidential reorganization plans by majority vote in both houses, but it expired years ago.

Myth: The President of the United States has limited power to order layoffs due to 5 USC Â§ 7513a, which creates a for-cause requirement for firings.

Truth: â€œReductions in forceâ€ are not covered by for-cause requirements. 5 U.S. Code Â§ 3502 expressly states that â€œreductions in forceâ€ are subject only to 60-day notice requirements and order-of-retention rules. The power to prescribe the â€œreduction in forceâ€ rules governing the â€œreductions in forceâ€ rest with the Office Personnel Management (OPM), and the current OPM rules give the power to effect â€œreductions in forceâ€ to agency heads. I will appoint agency heads who will execute large â€œreductions in force.â€

If agency heads do not cooperate, 5 U.S. Code Â§ 3302 empowers the President to override the OPM rules and drive the reductions in force directly. Note that the U.S. President is not an agency and thus not covered by the Administrative Procedures Act.

On March 23, 1966, in an accident that is now known as the Palomares incident, a B-52 bomber carrying four hydrogen bombs collided with a refueling tanker in Spain, and one of its nuclear weapons dropped into the sea.

As a U.S. Navy salvage team worked to recover the bomb, the towing line broke, sending a heavy steel pipe shooting toward the team â€” and in an incredible act of heroism, diver Carl Brashear threw himself in front of his men, taking the pipe in the leg.â 

Brashear not only survived, but he overcame extraordinary obstacles to get himself recertified as a master diver even though his leg had been removed, making him the first amputee diver in Navy history. Brashear was motivated by his beliefs that "It's not a sin to get knocked down; it's a sin to stay down" and "I ain't going to let nobody steal my dream."

For his service in helping to retrieve the bomb, Brashear was later awarded the   Navy and Marine Corps Medal, the highest navy award for non-combat heroism.
